Child MRI prep video and scanner sounds.main_content: Created by Pierce, Elizabeth , last updated on Apr 26, 2024 1 minute read You may decide to send these links to participants and their families and suggest they listen to the MRI sounds, practice holding still, and watch the video together. Perhaps encourage them to reach out and discuss any of their questions that arise during that process prior to their arrival at the center. Here is a link to some of the sounds from the MRI machine that may be listened to while practicing to lie down and hold still at home for 5-15 mins. at a time.  Increasing the volume of the sounds as practice continues is recommended.  Finger tips pressing the ears closed and hands covering the ears can be used to demonstrate the reduction of the loud noises that will occur when the earplugs and headphones are added prior to the MRI scan. http://bmap.ucla.edu/_media/ScannerNoises_Email_wASL.mp3 UCSF has provided a video to acquaint children with the MRI scanner but it may also be useful for older participants to view.  The link below is not our MRI machine but the short video provides a visual of the MRI experience.  Researchers are encouraged to view it first before deciding to send it to families. https://radiology.ucsf.edu/patient-care/for-patients/video/ucsf-radiology-getting-children-ready-mri Like Be the first to like this ucsf kb-how-to-article Edit Labels Write a comment... DICOM Transfer Guide - Neuroscape - Wiki.title: DICOM Transfer Guide - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF
DICOM Transfer Guide - Neuroscape - Wiki.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated by Pierce, Elizabeth on Feb 15, 2024 2 minute read Sending image data to Anubix2, PACS, R-VISAGE, DVDs Transferring Data Sending scan data to Anubix2 : Login to Anubix2. OsiriX is usually open but if not launch its icon in the dock. On the 3T Siemens Prisma console open up the Patient Browser and select the scan you want to transfer.  Make sure you select the entire scan by choosing the name in the first tree, and not just a single image or series unless that is desired.  Click on the ‘Send to…’ icon or go to ‘Transfer -> Send to’ on the menu bar.  Select Anubix2, and click the Send button. You may double click on the icon that appears on the bottom of the screen to monitor the transfer progress or the click on Transfer Log from the top of the screen. After the transfer is completed, go to Anubix2 then OsiriX and it will have a blue dot adjacent to the study name.  Note that blue dot/dial indicates the time it has been on Anubix2- not the amount of data transferred. Make sure all of the data has been transferred before pushing it to an external server or BOX.  The number of images sent are in a column on OsiriX and the Prisma's Transfer Log for matching reference, but notice a slight difference due to pushing the Phoenix Reports as their files are different sizes. Lab servers are added to Anubix2 by each group.  It is acceptable to leave the transfer running but each transfer will need to be checked and managed by the Lab. Burn data to a disc on Anubix2: To burn a CD/DVD, simply insert a blank disc into the drive.  Click OK when prompted to choose an action.  While holding down the option key drag the files you want to burn on top of the ‘Untitled CD/DVD’ icon that appears on the Desktop.  Once the transfer is complete, double click on the CD/DVD icon and click ‘Burn’ on the Finder window that you’ve just opened. Send sequences to Radiology PACS and R-VISAGE: Each project is responsible to arrange payment with Radiology for these reads.  Contact Prisma staff for details, elizabeth.pierce@ucsf.edu. On the 3T console open up the Patient Browser and select the sequences (T1, T2*, T2_, Axial Flair, etc.) you want to transfer.  Click on the ‘Send to…’ icon or go to ‘Transfer -> Send to’ on the menu bar.  For identified data read, select Apex , 2nd choice from the top of the list and click the Send button.  For de'ID data, select R-VISAGE and the click Send. Check the Transfer Log for status if desired. Note : The data in zip format may be stored on Aubix2 in Lab/Project folders on the desktop for less than one year. You may double click on the icon that appears on the bottom of the screen to monitor the transfer progress or the click on Transfer Log from the top of the screen. After the transfer is completed, go to Anubix2 then OsiriX and it will have a blue dot adjacent to the study name.  Note that blue dot/dial indicates the time it has been on Anubix2- not the amount of data transferred. Lab servers are added to Anubix2 by each group.  It is acceptable to leave the transfer running but each transfer will need to be checked and managed by the Lab.

Check the Transfer Log for status if desired.

This process can be time consuming, so please contact the Public Affairs team member who covers your area as soon as discussions begin, and copy Lara, lara.stables@ucsf.edu. MRGlasses - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF.title: MRGlasses - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF
MRGlasses - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated by Pierce, Elizabeth on Oct 21, 2023 3 minute read Function: Provides vision correction for participants inside the MRI scanner. Location and tips: The MR glasses are kept in plastic cases that sit on the right side of the table in our participant prep area. Note that our glasses are designed to only correct nearsightedness or farsightedness and not astigmatism. Astigmatisms correction is accomplished for their own glasses by individually modified curves added that help correct their unique vision. Since these lenses only curve one way, people with astigmatism might need to use + or - their usual script. Our lenses range from zero* to -8 or + 8. It takes 10 mins. or more to sort out the best ones for most participants. The case(s) may be taken from the Prisma suite in advance to fit the participant in another room so you do not burn scheduled scan time. *The reason there are zero lenses is for when someone only needs correction on one side and the frame needs two lenses to balance it on the participant's face. Putting lenses in frames: After you have chosen the lenses, gently spread the frames apart and pop in a lens one at a time.  L-lens into the left socket and R-lens into the right socket.  Wipe the lenses with the cloth if needed to remove finger prints, and the glasses are ready to wear. Note:  It helps to put an ear plug under the frame on the participant's nose to stabilize the frame and reduce fog.  The frame strap may be used to hold the frame on the participant's face, but most are more comfortable if you just place the frames on their face after they lie in the headcoil. ADDITIONAL DETAILS Reading the Prescription: A prescription from an optometrist is usually written in three numbers: For example: OD    -4.25 -1.75 X 180 OS    -5.50 -1.25 X 175 +2.25 Add OU OD ( lat. Ocular Dexter) is for the right eye, and OS ( lat. Ocular Sinister ) is for the left eye.  The 1st number (-4.25 and -5.50) is the degree of spherical nearsightedness or farsightedness.  The sign identifies whether you are nearsighted ( - ) or farsighted ( + ).  If you are nearsighted, your vision will become clearer the closer you stand to the eye chart. The second number (-1.75 and -1.25) is the degree of astigmatism. The number can be written either with a + sign or a - sign. The last and 3rd number (180 and 175) is the axis, or the direction of your astigmatism. An axis of 180 degrees, for example, means the astigmatism is horizontal. Therefore, this prescription means that the patient is moderately nearsighted, with a moderate degree of astigmatism in a horizontal direction. The "add" at the bottom of the prescription is for the reading part of a bifocal glass. It might be unusual for anyone under the age of 40 to need this. If the prescription only has one number, than the person does not have any astigmatism. Using the chart: Eyesight is commonly evaluated by reading a Snellen eye chart from a distance of 20 feet. Next to each row on the chart there is number 20/X, which provides a descriptive approximation of visual acuity.  A person with “ideal” eyesight will be able to read that row from X feet away.  Deviations from this “ideal” 20/20 can be caused by myopia (spherical lens correction required), astigmatism (cylindrical lens correction required) and other variables (including the lighting in the room).  If myopia is the only variable, the following approximate relationships exist between measurements in terms of diopters and the visual acuity, 20/X: Nearsightedness In Diopters 20/X Farsightedness In Diopters 20/X -0.5 20/25 – 20/30 +0.5 20/25 -1.0 20/30 – 20/50 +1.0 20/40 -3.0 20/300 +2.0 20/70 -4.0 20/400 +3.0 20/100 -5.0 20/600 +4.0 20/200 With the participant standing about 8 paces from the eye chart, hand them a lens one at a time and see which ones works best. Even though the frames and lenses are plastic, please use great care when handling them so they do not get scratched. Thank you. NNL - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF.title: NNL - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF
NNL - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated by Pierce, Elizabeth on May 01, 2023 1 minute read The scanner room monitor from NordicNeuroLab does not need software or physical adjusting.  Please contact Lara and Beth if you have questions regarding this. Step-by-step guide This unit's longevity depends on it not being left on when not in use. Please turn if off when you are done. There is a button on the front of the gray Power Supply in the back right corner of the scanner room. Push this on (green light) and off after each use. The flat wide side of the head coil mirror should face toward the monitor at the back of the bore. Position the head coil mirror over the participants eyes, so that they do not need to move their head to see. Neuroscape Scanner Lists - Neuroscape -.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated by Pierce, Elizabeth on Mar 13, 2023 1 minute read To manage your account settings, go to: https://listsrv.ucsf.edu/cgi-bin/wa Neuroscape Scanner lists: NIC_ACTIVE@listserv.ucsf.edu : for researchers actively using the NIC to be informed NIC_CANCEL@listserv.ucsf.edu : to notify users of scanner availability when you cancel a scan NIC-USERS@listserv.ucsf.edu : for anyone interested in using the NIC 3T To Subscribe: To subscribe to NIC_ACTIVE, email listserv@listserv.ucsf.edu with subscribe NIC_ACTIVE firstname lastname in the email body To subscribe to NIC_CANCEL, email listserv@listserv.ucsf.edu with subscribe NIC_CANCEL firstname lastname in the email body To subscribe to NIC-USERS, email listserv@listserv.ucsf.edu with subscribe NIC-USERS firstname lastname in the email body To Post : To post to NIC_ACTIVE, send an email to NIC_ACTIVE@listserv.ucsf.edu To post to NIC_CANCEL, send an email to NIC_CANCEL@listserv.ucsf.edu To post to NIC-USERS, send an email to NIC-USERS@listserv.ucsf.edu To post to NIC_FMRI, send an email to NIC_FMRI@listserv.ucsf.edu Like Be the first to like this kb-how-to-article Edit Labels Write a comment... Prisma Reboot Startup but do not Leave S.filename: Prisma Reboot Startup but do not Leave Shutdown - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF.html
Prisma Reboot Startup but do not Leave S.title: Prisma Reboot Startup but do not Leave Shutdown - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF
Prisma Reboot Startup but do not Leave S.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated by Pierce, Elizabeth on Sep 16, 2024 4 minute read CALL or TEXT Tech and Lara for help when you need to do this. Please DO NOT SHUTDOWN the scanner and leave the entire Prisma system OFF, even after the last scan of the day.  Siemens is monitoring the scanner remotely, so Please leave the scanner on after rebooting. Lock the scanner room door after last scan of the day. Note: Do not unplug or plug in any head coils or move the scanner bed while the system is actively shutting down or booting up to avoid time consuming table location lost error troubleshooting,  requiring reboot process and stress.  Even cleaning off the scanner bed or setting it up for your participant during shutdown or boot up will be enough movement to cause problems. Why?  Because the system will error if it fails to detect the table's location within millimeters.  The accuracy of this function helps measure the exact physical location of tumors, herniated discs, etc.  We can not bypass this internal check. This table reference test works best when the table is Home, up and out, as that is recognized as 0mm. Step-by-step guide Shutdown Procedure: Shutdown Procedure: 1. Ensure Participant Privacy by closing image data on the MRI scanner's computer monitor. Make sure all your scans have finished transferring to: SNC_Gateway, MAC, Anubix2, PACs - as is appropriate for your study. 2. In the Scanner Bay, Push the Home Button on the Control Pad (it looks like a little house) to leave the bed in the Home Position. Place used linens in the laundry basket. Replace any Pulse Ox, Button Box, equipment to their proper locations. Pick up any trash you have left in the Scanner Bay then proceed back to console after sealing the Pneumatic Door. 3. In the Menu Select "System" 4. Go to System | End Session… | Shutdown System… and press Yes to start the shutdown process. 5. Then click Shutdown System… and press Yes to start the shutdown process. Click OK to any warnings to proceed shutting down....now do a little email, text, or medicate. 6. After 7 or so minutes, the Siemens Console will let you know it is "Now safe to Turn off your Computer ". * Do not turn off the Console Computer which sits on the floor next to your feet; instead, turn System Off by moving to the left to the System Hardware Wall Interface.... 7. Press the BLUE SYSTEM OFF button on the Siemens Wall Panel to power down the system. Congratulate yourself, you are now ready to Turn off the Lights. Nice job! Proper Startup is Important too: Startup Procedure: Startup Procedure: Move the scanning computers mouse once to try and wake up the screen to be sure the last user finished the proper shutdown. This is a change from the last version of these instructions. If the message, "Now safe to Turn off your Computer ", appears on the monitor's screen, turn the system off * and wait 5 minutes before booting up per Siemens Applications Specialists aka super savvy users. This allows for all the hardware to complete its shutting down. If, after moving the mouse once no message appears on the scanning monitor's screen, proceed to item 4 of Proper Startup. Press the blue SYSTEM ON button on the Siemens Wall Panel to start the power up process. The system takes about 8 minutes to start.  The gradient icon on the bottom of the screen will have a red line through it – double click on it for more information but do not touch anything else to avoid errors. The Scanner will beep three times and the red line through the gradient icon will disappear when the scanner has finished booting up. If you do not notice the 3 beeps that is ok. As long as the red line is gone you may proceed. After ~8 minutes the scanner should be up and ready to Register your Patient. Remember to perform both Patient Registration screens prior to putting your subject onto the table. One must go through both screens prior to aligning the patient at Isocenter. Note: Do not unplug or plug in any head or body coils or move the bed while the system is starting because it will likely result in a startup error. If you have the first scan of the day, be sure you arrive with sufficient time so that you can start the Scanner with enough time to allow the System to properly initialize. Many times errors result from moving the table while the system is shutting down or booting up. Also, do not move any parts of the head coils during these functions. tables: Shutdown Procedure:
Shutdown Procedure:

1. Ensure Participant Privacy by closing image data on the MRI scanner's computer monitor. Make sure all your scans have finished transferring to: SNC_Gateway, MAC, Anubix2, PACs - as is appropriate for your study.

2. In the Scanner Bay, Push the Home Button on the Control Pad (it looks like a little house) to leave the bed in the Home Position. Place used linens in the laundry basket. Replace any Pulse Ox, Button Box, equipment to their proper locations. Pick up any trash you have left in the Scanner Bay then proceed back to console after sealing the Pneumatic Door.
3. In the Menu Select "System"
4. Go to System | End Session… | Shutdown System… and press Yes to start the shutdown process.
5. Then click Shutdown System… and press Yes to start the shutdown process. Click OK to any warnings to proceed shutting down....now do a little email, text, or medicate.

6. After 7 or so minutes, the Siemens Console will let you know it is "Now safe to Turn off your Computer ". * Do not turn off the Console Computer which sits on the floor next to your feet; instead, turn System Off by moving to the left to the System Hardware Wall Interface....
7. Press the BLUE SYSTEM OFF button on the Siemens Wall Panel to power down the system.
Startup Procedure:
Startup Procedure:

Move the scanning computers mouse once to try and wake up the screen to be sure the last user finished the proper shutdown. This is a change from the last version of these instructions. If the message, "Now safe to Turn off your Computer ", appears on the monitor's screen, turn the system off * and wait 5 minutes before booting up per Siemens Applications Specialists aka super savvy users. This allows for all the hardware to complete its shutting down. If, after moving the mouse once no message appears on the scanning monitor's screen, proceed to item 4 of Proper Startup. Press the blue SYSTEM ON button on the Siemens Wall Panel to start the power up process. The system takes about 8 minutes to start.  The gradient icon on the bottom of the screen will have a red line through it – double click on it for more information but do not touch anything else to avoid errors. The Scanner will beep three times and the red line through the gradient icon will disappear when the scanner has finished booting up. If you do not notice the 3 beeps that is ok. As long as the red line is gone you may proceed. After ~8 minutes the scanner should be up and ready to Register your Patient. Remember to perform both Patient Registration screens prior to putting your subject onto the table. One must go through both screens prior to aligning the patient at Isocenter.
Note: Do not unplug or plug in any head or body coils or move the bed while the system is starting because it will likely result in a startup error.

Scanner Troubleshooting Guide - Neurosca.title: Scanner Troubleshooting Guide - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF
Scanner Troubleshooting Guide - Neurosca.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated by Stables, Lara on Jul 17, 2017 2 minute read If you have problems with the scanner, check this list first! Problem: Unable to scan after pushing the ‘Table STOP’ button or using the ‘Table Release’ lever.  On the table-positioning panel this is indicated by the glowing ‘Stop’ button and the flashing ‘Table In/Out’ buttons. Solution: If the ‘Table STOP’ button was pushed, you should reset the table by pressing the ‘Table In’ & ‘Table Out’ in quick succession. (These buttons are on the table-positioning panel on the scanner itself and flash when the table is deactivated). If the ‘Table Release’ lever was pulled you need to make sure that the lever is back in its original position and the table is engaged (move the table back and forth along the track until you here a ‘click’).  Sometimes you need to move the table back to the home position before continuing (press the ‘home’ button on the table-positioning panel). Problem: The scanner stops in the middle of an EPI run with a red bar throught the "gradient" icon at the bottom of the screen and a message "Connection to the Reconstruction computer lost ... " (Note: This is a message that appears when you double click the "gradient" icon.) Solution: If the patient is inside the scanner pull them out!  Fully shut down the system and started back up -- a procedure that takes ~25 minutes. Problem: The Siemens console screen is blank after switching on the scanner. Solution: Hold the power button on Siemens computer until it shuts down, then push it again to turn it back on. Problem: Image contrast of an auto-loaded image is very bright (The image is very white when it should not be so.) Solution: Double-click the image with the middle mouse button. This is the shiny gray button with an indent. Double-clicking will return the image to its default contrast. The holding down the middle button allows you to alter contrast. Siemens Audio Systems Guide - Neuroscape.filename: Siemens Audio Systems Guide - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF.html
Siemens Audio Systems Guide - Neuroscape.title: Siemens Audio Systems Guide - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF
Siemens Audio Systems Guide - Neuroscape.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated on Jan 20, 2017 2 minute read MR compatible pneumatic sound system provided with the scanner did not arrive with headphones that would fit inside the 64-channel Head Coil, so we improvised these using a combination of the Old Trio and the New Prisma parts: Function: Primarily used to communicate with the subject, but could also be used to present simple tones during scanning. Location: The intercom is located in the Control room to the left of the Siemens Console Monitor.  The headphones are usually coiled up at the foot end of the patient table and plug into the yellow connector. Setup: Software: The setup is identical to Serene Sound Headphone.   Just make sure that sound output is set to USB Audio. Operation: Listening: Press the Listen button and adjust the volume using the increase/decrease adjacent buttons. Talking: Press and hold the Speak button. Presenting Audio:  Make sure the CV/CBT switch is switched to CV and the ‘Music’ button is pressed. Connections: The head phones are connected to the yellow opening at the foot of the patient bed. The central intercom unit is connected to the USB sound card via a dual RCA to 1/8” audio cable. fMRI Equipment Troubleshooting - Neurosc.title: fMRI Equipment Troubleshooting - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF
fMRI Equipment Troubleshooting - Neurosc.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated by Pierce, Elizabeth on Jan 02, 2024 2 minute read Video Problem: The NNL Screen is not turning on when connecting to the stim computer or your laptop. Solution: Make sure its power source in the Conditional MRI Area is glowing green. Problem: The NNL Screen turns on but then goes dark. Solution: The NNL v2.1 adapter may be needed to match your higher resolution. Solution: The HDMI cable's power source via USB from the Pure Link connector might need to be plugged in. Problem: The NNL Screen is not turning on when connecting to the stim computer or laptop. Solution: Make sure its power source in the Conditional MRI Area is glowing green. Audio Problem: No sound is coming through any of the MRI compatible headphones or earphones from the NIC stim computer or projects labtop. Solution: Check that the blue audio cable coming from any of the head/ear/phones talk boxes is connected to the stim computer via its green port or project laptop. Problem: No sound is coming through the Siemens headphones. Solution: Check that the blue audio cable coming from the stim computer is connected to the black booster cable coming from the Siemens talk box. Anubix2 Image Transfer Problem: Images are not appearing on Anubix2 after the transfer has been initiated. Solution: Make sure either Horos or OsiriX is running, not both launched, then restart the transfer from the Prisma. fORP - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF.title: fORP - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF
fORP - Neuroscape - Wiki@UCSF.main_content: Created by Chad Smiddy , last updated by Pierce, Elizabeth on May 01, 2023 4 minute read The 932 fORP System consists of Handheld Devices, a Fiber Optic Bundle, and an Interface Unit. Contact staff for setting up new projects. Function: Records subject responses while they are inside the MR scanner.  It may also be used for testing and training in the MR console area prior to scanning. Location: The Handheld Button Box and Joystick is located in the MRI scanner room and their cable and the Fiber Optic Bundle may be brought out into the MR console area for practice and troubleshooting.    The Interface Unit is in the Console room and is not permitted inside the MR scanner's room . Setup: Selecting Mode: Description Use the knob on the front Panel of the 932 Interface Unit to select the MODE appropriate to your setup.  Pushing the knob locks in the response and rotating the knob navigates the menu.  To select the Mode perform the following: Connect the device you'd like to use: Button Box or Joystick The fORP should be left in the Default state which is HID NAR 12345 for the Button Box.  The Button Box is usually connected. Push the knob IN and select YES Scroll down and select AUTOCONFIGURE Scroll down and select HID NAR 12345 How to Reconfigure the fORP for the Button Box from the Joystick Mode: These settings (FIU-005 HID NAR 12345) are for the Joystick so if you use the Button Box you must reconfigure the fORP. Push in the button on the fORP, then select Yes. With the device you'd like to use connected, select: AUTOCONFIGURE Scroll the knob to select HID NAR 12345 (the Trigger is a 5), with the Button Box connected you will see the Device Code (HHSC-1x4-L) on the fORP display. The Button Box has a sticker on it with this Device Code; shown here. Monitoring Responses: You can use the LED Array on the front panel of the 932 Interface Unit to monitor subject’s responses and the scanner trigger pulse. Detecting Responses PsychoPy Will not be upgraded at this time due to its incompatibility errors with Windows 10 Eprime and Presentation In the default mode (described above) register the 932 Interface as a Keyboard Input Device.  The buttons will register as Keyboard entries 1-4, and the trigger will register as Keyboard entry 5. Matlab (Psych Toolbox) You can use devices = PsychHID(‘devices’) command to identify the 932 Interface.  In that case, devices.product  is going to be ‘932’ and devices.usageName is going to be ‘Keyboard’.  If using the KbCheck command, the keys will register as keyCode 30 – 33 and the trigger will register as keyCode 34.  If identifying keys with KbName, use ‘1!’, ‘2@’, ‘3#’, ‘4$’ and ‘5%’. Connections: The handheld device is connected to the fiber optic bundle. The fiber optic bundle runs through the front waveguide and is connected to the Optical Port (P4) on the 932 Interface. The 932 Interface Unit is connected to the presentation computer via a USB cable (P3) through a USB Hub and a KVM Switch. The BNC cable is connected to the TTL TRIGGER Port (P6).
